course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Contemporary Architecture: The Pritzker Prize Winners
course.description: This course introduces students to the major international prizes in contemporary architecture, the foundation and awarding criteria of the Pritzker Architecture Prize, and the monographic studies of its winners from 1979 to the present. Architectural styles and works of the award winning design and functions, the most recent trends in architectural design and technology will be covered as well.

reviews.author: lmaoust
reviews.title: Good grading, fun course on architecture
reviews.comment_content:
It's about the architecture of 20th to 21st century. The first half of the semester is teaching while the second half is presentation of the Pritzker prize winners across the years.

Overall the contents are super simple, enjoyable to learn and listen to. It has raised interest in architecture. If I have time, I would have take this course again.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is very nice and friendly. The lessons are super interactive. She will response and explain to any questions that students raise in the lesson. So don't be shy asking!!!

Throughout the whole semester, each group will need to meet her twice for presentation consultation. She provided straight answers and insight ideas to improve the presentation.

One thing I found some classmates complaining was her accent is hard to be comfortable with.
reviews.comment_grading:
The professor embrace transparency in gradings. She even breakdown the scores of each individuals' in a group presentation.

Grade breakdown:
25% Project Presentation
25% Project Report
10% Consultation Meetings
20% Classwork (Essay)
20% Attendance and comments on peer presentations

There's no need to worry the architecture jargons, she looks for your understanding in aesthetic and history of the building more than the professional understanding.

Overall the grading is reasonably good. I got mean at the group presentation and above mean for the classwork. I got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
The main workload for the course is the project presentation, which is relatively easy comparing to other course.

As a student who studies two days and works three days a week, the workload is super light.

Strongly encourage people who have an interest in architecture to give it a try!!!

reviews.author: sleepy
reviews.title: If you enjoy architecture this course is very enjoyable
reviews.comment_content:
It is all about architecture. There will be only half a sem of teaching as the last 5-6 weeks would be used for presentations and the final assignment (classwork essay)

The course covers (from syllabus)
- Introduction
- Architecture of 20th and 21st Architecture
- America
- Modernism and beyond, in Japan, America, Europe
- Postmodernism
- Deconstruction and Hi-tech
- Critical Regionalism
- Recent Trends

The presentation architects are all Pritzer Prize laureates, like Leoh Ming Pewi, Norman Foster and Kenzo Tange to name a few. Content taught would be useful for the preparation of project presentations and reports, but of course, more research has to be done.

The classwork at the end is basically an in-class essay. You would be given around 1 hour to write on a topic, but you would need to quote from presentations from the prof and the project presentations.

I personally quite enjoy the content since I am very interested in architecture, but you can surely go sit in first to see how much are you interested. This course is also not always offered, so I grabbed my chance to study it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ngan is a very nice professor and she is very willing to answer emails and questions, or even start a meeting to answer you verbally. She also makes different prizes in the whole course to commemorate efforts. Since the class size is small, she remembers people's names if you attended the class and had consultation meetings with her.

However, one "can be better" point is that she is quite fluctuating in her comments, as my group had multiple meetings with her and she had different opinions on the same aspect we asked her (and had opposing views). I also think the previous reviews about her having vague instructions on the project presentation, report and the classwork without any good reference. However, I think it is adequate and it could be figured out eventually, so I did not think it was such big of a problem.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grades are very transparent as the professor would release all breakdown of each grade to each component (project report, presentation, final essay) of everyone so you would actually know how you are in the class. From what I observe, most of the class is in A-B range, only a number of people got C-D range. I think the distribution is fair as with the class size.

Grade breakdown:
25% Project Presentation
25% Project Report
10% Consultation Meetings
20% Classwork (Essay)
20% Attendance and comments on peer presentations

To clarify, the project itself includes work distribution stated clearly in the report and presentation, and the marks would be given individually. The groups are chosen at the start of the sem, and you choose based on the architect that you want to present. A good group at least could help you get the right direction but if you come without any friends (like me), you just choose one that you are interested in/see any trustworthy people in the group. You have the whole add-drop period to choose the group.
reviews.comment_workload:
The main workload is the project presentation, report, and prepping for the classwork. You could read extra readings provided for each lecture, but they are not required.

If your project group is the first few ones, you would have a tighter schedule in the middle of the semester since you would need to start working on your presentations and report earlier than others when you still do not have the full idea of how should it looks like. you have one week after the presentation to hand in the report. The earlier groups (Group 1-2) would have bonus marks because of this, and later on, you could rest before revising for the final classwork. That was a perk to me.

You need to prepare for 2 consultation meetings for the presentation, and present for 45 minutes (it may even be too little for you). And then you expected to hand in a 15-page report after one week (or two weeks for earlier groups). The classwork is after all presentations, at the last class. It is an open-book essay.

I think it all was manageable except that I was in the first few groups so at the middle of the semester it was quite packed for me. Otherwise, it is all good.

reviews.author: ghhhh
reviews.comment_content:
Pretty interesting.
It covers most of the styles in modern architecture.
Each class will be focusing on one specific architect and how his work involves.
There is a study trip to HSBC headquarter.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think she's pretty nice in general. She is willing to interact with you during or after class. We have a small class and she was able to remember every single one of us. She is knowledgeable in this area. The only thing is that the way she talks is really like calm and kinda slow. So for me personally, classes can sometimes sound a little bit boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is fair.
But since we had such a small class, and the grading is still curved so it's not exactly easy to get an A.
Group project (30%): choose an architect to do a 45-min presentation
Project report (30%): 15-page report based on your project and the comment you get from the presentation
Class discussion (15%)
Classwork (15%): sorta like an open-book writing task. It was a bit more writing than I expected. But since its open book and you can search whatever you want, it isn't too hard
Attendance and Comment on peer evaluation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is fine for a 3000level class.
There's no memorizing or anything that sort. You can choose to do the reading but in my opinion, it's not really necessary.
You don't have to do much throughout the first half of the class. And if you have nice groupmates, the project shouldn't be too difficult.

reviews.author: Colleen
reviews.title: good grade and interesting
reviews.comment_content:
as others said
much to learn
but I think it is acceptable as she has never asked as to memorize all the things taught and this is a 3000 course

the content is very interesting
it involves different styles in modern architecture and u could actually apply the knowledge when u see the buildings on streets so it is quite useful

the field trip to HSBC is very interesting too
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think she is a good teacher
by the end of the course, she is able to memorize the names of most of the students in the class (there are about 30 students in class although it is actually a lecture)
her teaching is quite good
she knows a lot about art and history
She is not that harsh as others said
She expects us to answer questions but u don't have to memorize all the contents as u can open the book and basically u just need to have an impression of the contents
reviews.comment_grading:
as others have mentioned it
I do not repeat it again
but the grading is quite good
also, she disclosed all the grades of students
so it is fair
but I do agree that the final classwork is very difficult as she has not explained clearly in class and the time given is very short but the grading is good and it is open-book. I did not finish the whole classwork but still get a higher mark than expected
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is not big as all things are open-book but u still have to revise before the only classwork as there are too many things involved in the classwork
The group project is not very difficult but it depends on who is your group mate
Although peer review is provided, only 3 people form a group.
But no other things are involved.

reviews.author: chimz
reviews.title: A / B-range 加埋有7成嘅好Grade course
reviews.comment_content:
課堂內容非常多，一堂平均PPT會超過60版，由1900年開始講起:
Modernism: Celebration of Machinery Age
(Le Corbusier...)
Vernacular Architecture
Organic Architecture

Post-modernism: Vibrancy and Localisation
Historical Revivalism
Critical Regionalism
Deconstruction
Hi-tech / Green Architecture
Recent trend of awarding Pritzker Prize
syllabus嘅野非常多，堂堂都有好多野可以記
reviews.comment_teaching:
佢會叫人搶答問題，但答咗都要論錯對，啱佢就會記低，所以次次上堂前請做足功課，因為你俾佢記低咗名，先代表你有上堂，否則人在都係無用。另外，佢上堂會邊講書，邊記低d人遲到嘅時間，大概上堂遲半個鐘嗰d就會記，無返學嗰d都會記低。

呢個course要做group project, 如果你課外時間搵先生傾，佢會願意教嘅。
佢會好重視大家付出幾多，但方法有d奇怪，同埋有d幼稚。

同埋final exam (即係堂上考嘅classwork)從來都無同我地講過題目，搞到就算open book，都考得好差，因為完全under-prepare。
reviews.comment_grading:
Project + Presen (60%) 組員之間分數唔一定一樣，先生俾分係會按你嘅分工調節，某程度上係多勞多得。

Exam (15%)最後一堂考，open book, open computer, 題目係: Illustrate Contemporary Architecture concepts with Pritzker Prize winners as examples, 一個point 0.5分，即成篇文一個鐘內要有30個point，所以大家要組織好抄邊度，先好去考。PPT 嘅內容未必夠，所以大家要專心聽書。

Attendance (10%)學生presen嘅時間計，無去一個直接扣1分

Participation (15%) 搶答(5%) + peer evaluation form 我地寫嘅內容有無建設性 (10%)

Presen: mean: 19.08, s.d. 4.6, highest: 28
Written report: mean: 17.88, s.d. 4.49, highest: 25
peer evaluation form (10%): mean: 2.18, highest: 8
final exam: mean: 6.62, s.d. 3.2, highest: 14

呢個course可能人少，grade非常好
A-range: 18.5% (總分: 72+)
B-range: 51.9% (總分: 54+)
C / D-range: 22.2% (總分: 39-52)
F: 7.41%
無A+
reviews.comment_workload:
如果要認真，其實可以睇好多書、資料去爭答問題，要hea，其實都可以就咁坐係度，考好個試，都可以好grade，悉隨尊便。

都係嗰句: 多勞多得
